verb.definition: Begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
verb.example: manufacturers are keen to cash in on the burgeoning demand

verb.definition: Polish (something, especially metal) by rubbing.
verb.example: highly burnished armor

noun.definition: The shine on a highly polished surface.
A projecting support of stone or brick built against a wall.
A source of defense or support.
noun.example: there was a demand for a new stable order as a buttress against social collapse

verb.definition: Provide (a building or structure) with projecting supports built against its walls.
verb.example: we buttressed the wall as it was showing signs of cracking and collapse

verb.definition: Increase the strength of or justification for; reinforce.
verb.example: authority was buttressed by religious belief

verb.definition: Ask for or obtain (something to which one is not strictly entitled)
verb.example: he eats whenever he can cadge a meal

noun.definition: A padded wooden frame on which hooded hawks are carried to the field.

adjective.definition: Showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.
adjective.example: his callous comments about the murder made me shiver

noun.definition: variant spelling of callus
The making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation; slander.
noun.example: a bitter struggle marked by calumny and litigation

noun.definition: An unfounded rumor or story.
noun.example: the old canard that LA is a cultural wasteland

noun.definition: A small winglike projection attached to an aircraft forward of the main wing to provide extra stability or control, sometimes replacing the tail.

meaning: an established set of principles; a basis or standard for judgment; a group of literary works

noun.definition: archaic spelling of canyon
A general law, rule, principle, or criterion by which something is judged.
noun.example: the appointment violated the canons of fair play and equal opportunity

noun.definition: A collection or list of sacred books accepted as genuine.
noun.example: the formation of the biblical canon

noun.definition: (in the Roman Catholic Church) the part of the Mass containing the words of consecration.
A piece in which the same melody is begun in different parts successively, so that the imitations overlap.
A member of the clergy who is on the staff of a cathedral, especially one who is a member of the chapter. The position is frequently conferred as an honorary one.
noun.example: he was appointed canon of Christ Church, Oxford

meaning: insincere talk; language of a particular group

noun.definition: Hypocritical and sanctimonious talk, typically of a moral, religious, or political nature.
noun.example: the liberal case against all censorship is often cant

noun.definition: Language peculiar to a specified group or profession and regarded with disparagement.
noun.example: thieves' cant

verb.definition: Talk hypocritically and sanctimoniously about something.
verb.example: if they'd stop canting about “honest work,” they might get somewhere

verb.definition: Cause (something) to be in a slanting or oblique position; tilt.
verb.example: he canted his head to look at the screen

noun.definition: A slope or tilt.
noun.example: the outward cant of the curving walls

noun.definition: A wedge-shaped block of wood, especially one remaining after the better-quality pieces have been cut off.

adjective.definition: Bad-tempered, argumentative, and uncooperative.
adjective.example: a crusty, cantankerous old man

meaning: faultfinding; intended to entrap; as in an argument;

adjective.definition: (of a person) tending to find fault or raise petty objections.
adjective.example: a captious teacher

noun.definition: A leading dignitary of the Roman Catholic Church. Cardinals are nominated by the Pope, and form the Sacred College which elects succeeding popes (now invariably from among their own number).
A New World songbird of the bunting family, with a stout bill and typically with a conspicuous crest. The male is partly or mostly red in color.

adjective.definition: Of the greatest importance; fundamental.
adjective.example: two cardinal points must be borne in mind

meaning: of the flesh or body; related to physical appetities

adjective.definition: Relating to physical, especially sexual, needs and activities.
adjective.example: carnal desire

adjective.definition: Difficult to please; critical.
adjective.example: she has silenced the carping critics with a successful debut tour

noun.definition: The science or practice of drawing maps.

meaning: any of the hereditary social classes in Hindu society; social stratification

noun.definition: Each of the hereditary classes of Hindu society, distinguished by relative degrees of ritual purity or pollution and of social status.
noun.example: members of the lower castes

meaning: a violent upheaval that causes great destruction and change

noun.definition: A large-scale and violent event in the natural world.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.

adjective.definition: Unambiguously explicit and direct.
adjective.example: a categorical assurance

noun.definition: (in some US states) a meeting at which local members of a political party register their preference among candidates running for office or select delegates to attend a convention.
noun.example: Hawaii holds its nominating caucuses next Tuesday

noun.definition: A conference of members of a legislative body who belong to a particular party or faction.
noun.example: Mr. Kerry attended the morning caucus in the Old Senate Chamber where his fellow Democrats selected the new minority leadership

noun.definition: A group within an organization or political party which meets independently to discuss strategy or tactics.
noun.example: up to fifty caucuses met daily on conference grounds to discuss lobbying strategies

verb.definition: Hold or form a legislative caucus.
verb.example: Republicans briefly caucused

adjective.definition: Relating to or acting as a cause.
adjective.example: the causal factors associated with illness

adjective.definition: Able to burn or corrode organic tissue by chemical action.
adjective.example: a caustic cleaner

adjective.definition: Sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
adjective.example: the players were making caustic comments about the refereeing

adjective.definition: Formed by the intersection of reflected or refracted parallel rays from a curved surface.

noun.definition: A caustic substance.
A caustic surface or curve.

meaning: concerned with sky or heavens; sublime

adjective.definition: Positioned in or relating to the sky, or outer space as observed in astronomy.
adjective.example: a celestial body

adjective.definition: Moving or tending to move away from a center.

meaning: moving or directed toward a center

adjective.definition: Moving or tending to move toward a center.

noun.definition: A person who has defeated or surpassed all rivals in a competition, especially in sports.
noun.example: a champion hurdler

noun.definition: A person who fights or argues for a cause or on behalf of someone else.
noun.example: a champion of women's rights

verb.definition: Support the cause of; defend.
verb.example: priests who championed human rights

meaning: to correct by punishment or reproof; to restrain or subdue

verb.definition: (of a rebuke or misfortune) have a restraining or moderating effect on.
verb.example: the director was somewhat chastened by his recent flops
synonyms: take down a peg or two

noun.definition: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose.
noun.example: an underhanded person who schemes corruption and political chicanery behind closed doors

meaning: the qualities idealized by knighthood such as bravery and gallantry toward women

noun.definition: The medieval knightly system with its religious, moral, and social code.

adjective.definition: Rude in a mean-spirited and surly way.
adjective.example: it seems churlish to complain

adjective.definition: (of a route or journey) longer than the most direct way.
adjective.example: the canal followed a circuitous route

noun.definition: A loud and confused noise, especially that of people shouting vehemently.
noun.example: the questions rose to a clamor

verb.definition: (of a group of people) shout loudly and insistently.
verb.example: the surging crowds clamored for attention

noun.definition: A small group of people, with shared interests or other features in common, who spend time together and do not readily allow others to join them.
noun.example: the old-school clique

noun.definition: A covered walk in a convent, monastery, college, or cathedral, typically with a wall on one side and a colonnade open to a quadrangle on the other.

verb.definition: Seclude or shut up in or as if in a convent or monastery.
verb.example: the monastery was where the Brothers would cloister themselves to meditate

verb.definition: (of a fluid, especially blood) change to a solid or semisolid state.
verb.example: blood had coagulated around the edges of the wound

verb.definition: Come together to form one mass or whole.
verb.example: the puddles had coalesced into shallow streams

meaning: concluding part of a literary or musical composition; something that summarizes or concludes

noun.definition: The concluding passage of a piece or movement, typically forming an addition to the basic structure.

verb.definition: Arrange (laws or rules) into a systematic code.

adjective.definition: Having knowledge or being aware of.
adjective.example: statesmen must be cognizant of the political boundaries within which they work

meaning: artistic composition of materials pasted over a surface; an assemblage of diverse elements

noun.definition: A piece of art made by sticking various different materials such as photographs and pieces of paper or fabric on to a backing.

adjective.definition: Corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
adjective.example: salary will be commensurate with experience

noun.definition: A collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject, especially in a book or other publication.

adjective.definition: Showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.
adjective.example: you can't afford to be complacent about security

meaning: overly polite; willingness to comply with the wishes of others

adjective.definition: Willing to please others; obliging; agreeable.
adjective.example: when unharnessed, Northern dogs are peaceful and complaisant

meaning: something that completes or makes up a whole

noun.definition: A thing that completes or brings to perfection.
noun.example: the libretto proved a perfect complement to the music

noun.definition: A number or quantity of something, especially that required to make a group complete.
noun.example: at the moment we have a full complement of staff

noun.definition: One or more words, phrases, or clauses governed by a verb (or by a nominalization or a predicative adjective) that complete the meaning of the predicate.
A group of proteins present in blood plasma and tissue fluid which combine with an antigen–antibody complex to bring about the lysis of foreign cells.

verb.definition: Add to (something) in a way that enhances or improves it; make perfect.
verb.example: a classic blazer complements a look that's stylish or casual

adjective.definition: Inclined to agree with others or obey rules, especially to an excessive degree; acquiescent.
adjective.example: a compliant labor force

adjective.definition: Having the property of compliance.

noun.definition: A feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows the doing of something bad.
noun.example: spend the money without compunction

adjective.definition: Having an outline or surface that curves inward like the interior of a circle or sphere.
adjective.example: concave lenses

adjective.definition: Intended or likely to placate or pacify.
adjective.example: a conciliatory approach
synonyms: so as to pour oil on troubled waters

meaning: similar in tastes and habits; friendly; suited to
expert in matters of taste; expert knowledge or training
a person compulsorily enrolled for military service
touching; neighboring; connecting without a break
very sorrowful for a wrong; seeking forgiveness

noun.definition: A confusing and difficult problem or question.
noun.example: one of the most difficult conundrums for the experts

meaning: practice widely observed in a group; custom; accepted technique or device

noun.definition: A way in which something is usually done, especially within a particular area or activity.
noun.example: the woman who overturned so many conventions of children's literature

noun.definition: An agreement between countries covering particular matters, especially one less formal than a treaty.
A large meeting or conference, especially of members of a political party or a particular profession.
noun.example: a convention of retail merchants

noun.definition: An artificial bid by which a bidder tries to convey specific information about the hand to their partner.

meaning: to approach; come together; tend to meet

verb.definition: (of lines) tend to meet at a point.
verb.example: a pair of lines of longitude are parallel at the equator but converge toward the poles

verb.definition: (of a series) approximate in the sum of its terms toward a definite limit.
verb.example: the powers of e therefore converge very slowly

adjective.definition: Having an outline or surface curved like the exterior of a circle or sphere.
adjective.example: a convex lens

adjective.definition: (of a polygon) having only interior angles measuring less than 180°.
(of an atmosphere or event) friendly, lively, and enjoyable.
adjective.example: a convivial cocktail party

adjective.definition: (especially of an argument, story, or sentence) extremely complex and difficult to follow.
adjective.example: its convoluted narrative encompasses all manner of digressions

adjective.definition: Intricately folded, twisted, or coiled.
adjective.example: walnuts come in hard and convoluted shells

adjective.definition: Abundant in supply or quantity.
adjective.example: she took copious notes

noun.definition: A woman who flirts.
noun.example: her transformation from an ice maiden warrior into a winsome coquette

noun.definition: A crested Central and South American hummingbird, typically with green plumage, a reddish crest, and elongated cheek feathers.

meaning: horn overflowing with fruit and grain; state of abundance

noun.definition: A symbol of plenty consisting of a goat's horn overflowing with flowers, fruit, and corn.

meaning: study of the universe as a totality; theory of the origin and structure of the universe

noun.definition: The science of the origin and development of the universe. Modern astronomy is dominated by the Big Bang theory, which brings together observational astronomy and particle physics.

adjective.definition: Not openly acknowledged or displayed.
adjective.example: covert operations against the dictatorship

noun.definition: A thicket in which game can hide.
Any of the feathers covering the bases of the main flight or tail feathers of a bird.

adjective.definition: Having or showing a great desire to possess something belonging to someone else.
adjective.example: she fingered the linen with covetous hands

meaning: to mislead by trick or fraud; decieve

verb.definition: Trick or deceive.
verb.example: do not think to cozen your contemporaries

adjective.definition: Contemptibly lacking in courage; cowardly.
adjective.example: a craven abdication of his moral duty

noun.definition: A cowardly person.
Belief in or acceptance of something as true.
noun.example: psychoanalysis finds little credence among laymen

noun.definition: A small side table, shelf, or niche in a church for holding the elements of the Eucharist before they are consecrated.
noun.example: a credence table

meaning: statement of belief or principle; creed

noun.definition: A statement of the beliefs or aims which guide someone's actions.
noun.example: he announced his credo in his first editorial

verb.definition: Make (someone) feel intimidated or apprehensive.
verb.example: some people are daunted by technology

noun.definition: A scarcity or lack of something.
noun.example: there is a dearth of evidence

noun.definition: Excessive indulgence in sensual pleasures.
Behavior in keeping with good taste and propriety.
noun.example: you exhibit remarkable modesty and decorum

verb.definition: Damage the good reputation of (someone); slander or libel.
verb.example: he claimed that the article defamed his family

noun.definition: Failure to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or appear in a court of law.
noun.example: it will have to restructure its debts to avoid default

noun.definition: A preselected option adopted by a computer program or other mechanism when no alternative is specified by the user or programmer.
noun.example: the default is fifty lines

verb.definition: Fail to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or to appear in a court of law.
verb.example: some had defaulted on student loans

verb.definition: (of a computer program or other mechanism) revert automatically to (a preselected option)
verb.example: when you start a fresh letter the system will default to its own style

noun.definition: Humble submission and respect.
noun.example: he addressed her with the deference due to age

adjective.definition: No longer existing or functioning.
adjective.example: a now defunct technology that only people over a certain age remember

verb.definition: Describe or portray (something) precisely.
verb.example: the law should delineate and prohibit behavior that is socially abhorrent

adjective.definition: Relating to the structure of populations.
adjective.example: the demographic trend is toward an older population

noun.definition: A particular sector of a population.
noun.example: the drink is popular with a young demographic

adjective.definition: Denoting or relating to the kind of language used by ordinary people; popular or colloquial.
adjective.example: a demotic idiom

noun.definition: Ordinary colloquial speech.

meaning: to express doubt; question or oppose

verb.definition: Raise doubts or objections or show reluctance.
verb.example: normally she would have accepted the challenge, but she demurred

noun.definition: The action or process of objecting to or hesitating over something.
noun.example: they accepted this ruling without demur

verb.definition: Criticize unfairly; disparage.
verb.example: there is a tendency to denigrate the poor

noun.definition: An inhabitant or occupant of a particular place.
noun.example: denizens of field and forest

meaning: outcome; unraveling of the plot of a play or work of literature

noun.definition: The final part of a play, movie, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together and matters are explained or resolved.

meaning: one who can predict the future; psychic

noun.definition: A person who claims to have a supernatural ability to perceive events in the future or beyond normal sensory contact.

adjective.definition: Having or exhibiting an ability to perceive events in the future or beyond normal sensory contact.
adjective.example: he didn't tell me about it and I'm not clairvoyant

verb.definition: Express contempt for; ridicule.
verb.example: critics derided the proposals as clumsy attempts to find a solution
